awd_titl_txt: Multidimensional Materials Assembled by DNA Based Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry.  Professors Nadrian C. Seeman, and James W. Canary of New York University are supported to develop novel self-assembly approaches for controlling the orientation of polymer strands in confined spaces.  The polymeric material will be directed to assemble based on information contained in pre-programmed branched-DNA scaffolds.  The polymer strands are incorporated within the scaffolds with specified orientation and spacing to generate specific optical and electronic properties.  Polymer-based organic materials have a wide range of practical applications, including in optical, electronic and solar energy conversion devices.  Their properties depend not only on the chemical structure of the polymer, but also on the orientation of the polymer strands. Graduate and undergraduate students are trained in an interdisciplinary area of research.  In addition, technical and educational activities are directed towards high school and college science students especially from underrepresented minorities. 

The project aims to develop a general strategy to organize conjugated oligomers and polymers by combining organic synthesis with pre-programmed DNA self-assembly.  Specifically, this research investigates the incorporation of two types of semiconducting conjugated molecules -- oligopolyaniline (PANI) and poly- (p-phenylene vinylene) (PPV) -- in cage-like DNA nanoscale scaffolds and studies their elecrto-optical properties.  The key experimental features are to control the length of the oligomers through stepwise organic synthesis and to covalently attached the oligomers to DNA strands.  The general strategy is not limited to PANI and PPV; it can be applied to other oligomers with different electro-optical properties, as well as to fluorescent dyes, nanoparticles, and functional peptides.  Study of how DNA scaffolds can be used to direct the assembly of these conjugated molecules is expected to provide insightful fundamental information about their structure/function relationships, which could eventually lead to new types of functional materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research project used the programmability of DNA to assemble electronic components as small as single molecules to achieve two- and three- dimensional structures with emergent properties. No self-assembly system is more programmable than DNA using tools developed in these laboratories. By choosing the correct sequence of 4 DNA bases, 2D and 3D objects can be easily assembled with nanometer scale features. This project yielded new DNA structures never before characterized, including hexagonal crystals that contain large pore sizes and are a significant extension of periodic 3D material that can be assembled using DNA. Stabilization of DNA crystals was achieved through optimization of the attractive moieties that cause multiple DNA molecules to assemble together.

The central focus of this project was to attach organic molecules with electronic and optical properties to DNA, and assemble objects that show new properties not seen in the separate components. The organic materials polyaniline and polyphenylenevinylene were chosen to assemble using DNA techniques. Polyaniline exhibits remarkable conductive and oxidation/reduction properties for an organic material. A well-defined fragment of polyaniline (octaniline) was selected for the study. A conjugate of DNA and octaniline was found to be freely soluble in water, which is surprising as octaniline itself is practically insoluble in all solvents. This conjugate formed dimers that showed coupling of the electronic absorbance of the polymer backbone. A 3D array of DNA with octaniline showed optical and electrochemical behavior that resembled that of the widely known organic polymer, polyaniline. However, the DNA/octaniline assembly was shown to respond far more efficiently to oxidation and reduction than analogous polymer films.

Polyphenylenevinylene is another important organic material that displays strong optical properties. In this study the molecular fragment heptaphenylenevinylene (HPV) was chosen for incorporation into DNA crystals. HPV shows excellent optical properties similar to the polymer, polyphenylenevinylene (PPV). The DNA-HPV structure gave highly polarized fluorescence emission, indicating its rigid orientation within the DNA crystal. Such properties could be useful in fabricating optical switches and computers.

Carbon nanotubes show great promise as components of electronic devices, but they are difficult or impossible to process. Self-assembly methods are needed to be able to direct them to specified locations for device fabrication. This project demonstrated that this can be done using DNA two-dimensional structures for assembly. One or two carbon nanotubes were located at specified positions and orientations on DNA structures. This represents an important step forward towards methods that can be used to manufacture carbon nanonube-based electronics.

The research engaged students at a variety of levels from high school through graduate students. There were at least five high school students, two C-STEP students, two international Master's students, and 55 undergraduates engaged in the project. All of these individuals went through the basic training in the laboratory, and many participated in projects leading to publications. More advanced students were trained in DNA structural nanotechnology and materials and device design and fabrication.

The broader community was engaged through ongoing symposia series on nanoscience, curricular development, and other service by the principal investigators on the project.

 


Last Modified: 01/20/2022
Modified by: James W Canary
